text: Mr. Spicer: Good afternoon, everyone.
I wanted to wait until the President finished up with
his remarks on the budget before I came out.
As you saw, he&#39;s -- a really good opportunity to
sit down with his team.
It&#39;s clearly been a busy day here at the White
House again, so I&#39;m going to kind of keep it quick
and get to your questions.
This morning, after receiving his daily
intelligence briefing, the President met with
Secretary of State Tillerson.
As you all know, Secretary Tillerson and Secretary
Kelly will travel to Mexico City later today as
one of their first foreign trips.
It&#39;s significant that the President is sending
the secretaries to Mexico
so early in the administration.
It&#39;s symbolic of the meaningful relationship
that our two nations have.
These are important meetings regarding the
President&#39;s agenda to improve the quality of
lives for people of Mexico and the United States by
combatting drug traffickers and finding
ways to bolster both our economies through a
broader relationship that promotes commerce
and legal immigration.
This is a very encouraging start to a working
relationship with an
incredible neighbor to the south.
At this moment, the President has just wrapped
up his discussions on the federal budget with some
of the officials and staff who will be instrumental
in the work to put this country back on a
responsibly fiscal path.
Joining the meeting were Reince Priebus, the Chief
of Staff; Steve Bannon; Jared Kushner; Gary Cohn,
the Director of the National Economic Council;
Secretary Steve Mnuchin of the Department of
Treasury; Director Mulvaney of the Office of
Management and Budget; Russ Vought of the Office
of Management and Budget; and Emma Doyle of Office
of Management and Budget.
As the President mentioned last week, we look forward
to presenting our tax reform plan and providing
much-needed tax reform and relief to the hardworking
men and women of our nation.
The President is going to restore and respect the
American taxpayer by enabling them to keep more
of their hard-earned money, and by making sure
the federal government
spends money more responsibly.
After the lunch, the President will continue
this important discussion with other members of the
senior staff.
Additionally, the Vice President today is in
St. Louis to participate in listening sessions with
American workers and employees of the Fabick
Cat equipment and engineer* [engine] dealer,
a 100-year-old family-owned and
operated business.
During his visit, the Vice President will discuss the
economic comeback in store for our nation under the
President&#39;s economic agenda and with small
business owners and employees.
The President has already made strides towards
slashing redundant regulations through his
executive actions, and we will work with Congress to
enact further pro-growth legislation.
Back to the President&#39;s schedule.
Later this afternoon, the President will participate
in his standing legislative affairs
strategy session.
Our legislative affairs team is in constant
contact with our counterparts on the Hill,
keeping an open dialogue on all aspects of the
President&#39;s agenda.
Last week alone, more than 40 different senators and
members of Congress visited the White House.
On the Supreme Court front, so far Judge
Gorsuch has met with 58 senators -- 36 Republicans
and 22 Democrats -- and he has more meetings already
on the books for next week when the Senate
returns to session.
We&#39;ve been especially encouraged by the
reception he&#39;s received from several senior
Democrats, including Senators Feinstein,
Tester, Durbin, and Gillibrand.
Also on the confirmation front, multiple unions
came out today for Alex Acosta, the President&#39;s
nominee for Labor Secretary.
Both the Laborers&#39; International Union of
North America and the International Union of
Operating Engineers praised his distinguished
career and pledged their support
for his nomination.
The legislative affairs team is using the
congressional work period to coordinate with key
coalitions in Congress.
They are meeting with different groups in the
House and Senate, including the staff of the
Congressional Black Caucus, House and Senate
leadership, and staff throughout various committees.
We&#39;ve used this work period as an opportunity
to invite staffers from both sides of the aisle to
come to the White House and discuss shared
priorities and find common ground on the way forward.
And we&#39;re not just reaching out to Capitol
Hill, we&#39;ve actively engaged with key leaders
and policymakers around the country.
It&#39;s critical to this administration that we
gather input from states and from people throughout
the country, rather than
just leaders here in Washington.
Looking ahead to tomorrow, the President will meet
with a group of world-class business
leaders to discuss specific actions he can
take to remove barriers to job creation.
These leaders, many of whom represent some of the
country&#39;s largest manufacturers, will begin
the day in working groups with the Vice President,
Cabinet members and key
aides of the President&#39;s staff.
The working groups will engage in a deep-dive
conversation on the attendees&#39; specific
areas of expertise.
Topics of discussion include deregulation, tax
and trade, training and the workforce of the
future, and infrastructure Vice President Pence will
be engaged with each of the groups.
And after the groups conclude their discussion,
the President&#39;s staff will compile the feedback and
the President will sit down with the entire group
for a listening session
on some of their recommendations.
As you can tell by the structure of the meeting,
the President is expecting these interactions to lead
to real action being taken by the administration.
Creating a dynamic and booming economy that works
for all Americans continues to be at the top
of his domestic policy agenda.
As a successful businessman himself, the
President knows that if we&#39;re going to get the
country back to work, we need to hear directly from
job creators what is holding them back, and,
where appropriate, take
steps to remove the barriers.
In his first month in office, the President has
already taken numerous actions to boost job
creation, and key economic indicators are showing
that it&#39;s working.
CEO and [consumer] confidence are up, the
stock market continues to reach record highs, and
the January numbers were strong.
The meetings on Thursday will continue to build
on that momentum.
And with that, I&#39;m glad to take some questions.
Steve Holland.
THE PRESS: Steve Holland is not here.
Mr. Spicer: Sorry, Jeff Mason gets it.
(Laughter.)
The Press: Thank you, Sean.
Can you give us an update on the administration&#39;s
plans with regard to transgender
bathrooms in schools?
And can you confirm that there has been some
disagreement between Secretary DeVos and the
Attorney General on this issue?
Mr. Spicer: So I would expect further guidance to
come out on that today.
The President, as I said yesterday, is a firm
believer in states&#39; rights.
When you look at the guidance that was issued
under the Obama administration -- first of
all, let&#39;s remember, to the best of my knowledge,
that was stalled and never fully implemented.
And I think there were various reasons for that
-- several legal reasons and several
procedural reasons.
And so the Department of Education and the
Department of Justice, both who jointly issued
that guidance back during the Obama administration,
are now working together again under a Trump
administration, they&#39;ve been reviewing the
guidance that was signed, the basis by which
it was put through.
And I think there have been several areas of
concern, both legal and procedural, that they have
been discussing.
And I think where you might be hearing something
is more on the timing and the wording of stuff.
The conclusions, everybody in the administration
is agreed upon.
There is no daylight between anybody -- between
the President, between any of the Secretaries.
I think there has been some discussion between
the timing of the issuance and recommendations, or
between the exact wording.
But as far as the conclusions go, I&#39;ve made
this clear and the President has made it
clear throughout the campaign that he is a firm
believer in states&#39; rights and that certain issues
like this are not best dealt with at
the federal level.
The Press: Sean, a report out today that some
Cabinet Secretaries are bristling at what they see
as the White House micromanaging staffing at
the sub-Cabinet level.
To what degree does the White House think that it
should impose its hiring approvals on members of
the sub-Cabinet?
And is some of this at least partially driven by
Cabinet Secretaries wanting to appoint people
who might not necessarily be aligned with the
President&#39;s thinking?
Mr. Spicer: Well, I mean, I think when you come to
-- they&#39;re called political appointees
for a reason.
The idea is that people who come into this
government should want to support and enact the
President&#39;s agenda that he campaigned on with the
American people.
And I think one of the reasons that you see in
recent polls the President -- people, even if they
don&#39;t agree with the President, they give him
high marks for following through on the promises
that he&#39;s made to the American people and
getting things done that he actually said, which is
not always the case here in Washington.
And I think that we want to make sure that the
people who staff a Trump administration are
committed to a Trump agenda, and that&#39;s -- so
Cabinet Secretaries and other administrators and
directors have broad discretion.
But I think at the end of the day, no matter what
position you have -- whether it&#39;s the lowest or
the highest in the White House or in a department
or agency -- we should be making sure that people
who are coming in as appointees of the
President support the President&#39;s agenda.
And I think that&#39;s one thing -- this isn&#39;t about
getting a job as a federal employee where you&#39;re
subject to certain restrictions as to what
you can and can&#39;t do as a benefit of being
a federal employee.
These are political appointees, and so I think
that there is obviously -- we are going to ensure
that people who are political appointees share
the vision and agenda that the President campaigned
on and is implementing.
The Press: And does the White House believe that
it needs to have the final approval of these people
or can you trust your Cabinet Secretaries to --
Mr. Spicer: It&#39;s not a question of trust.
It&#39;s a question of just making sure that we&#39;re all
on the same page and committed to the same
agenda that the President has set forth.
This process is probably no different than we&#39;ve
seen in previous administrations.
Cabinet Secretaries come to the President with
recommendations on who they want, and it depends
on the position, obviously.
But in certain cases, if they&#39;re going to fulfill a
job that is a key area that the President had
very specific goals to enact that he promised the
American people, you want to make sure that the
person that is fulfilling that job actually is
committed to the agenda and the vision that the
President set forth and promised the American people.
And that&#39;s -- so there is -- that&#39;s something that
we&#39;re always going to be making sure
is in alignment.
The Press: And is this approval process in some
way slowing down the appointment of
crucial staffers?
Mr. Spicer: No.
No, not at all.
I don&#39;t think so.
I think when you look across where we are and we
track the number of folks that are in the pipeline,
we&#39;re doing very, very well with getting all of
these positions filled.
And I think once in a while, you might hear of
one or two people, but overall, generally
speaking, I mentioned during the transition
period how many members of the beachhead teams that
we had, and I think we -- those members who are
pointed through the beachhead process
had 120 days.
And they were there to allow basically a
four-month process for Secretaries in the White
House to make sure that people on a permanent
basis could populate those positions.
And that&#39;s what&#39;s happening.
But make no mistake -- I mean, we were ahead of the
curve on the beachhead teams.
We were very clear with the landing teams during
the transition.
This has been a very methodical process that
has seen from top to bottom through, and I
think we&#39;re doing a phenomenal job
of staffing the government.
Margaret.
The Press: Thank you.
Oh, which Margaret?
Mr. Spicer: Oh, lucky me.
(Laughter.)
The Press: Two Margarets.
I&#39;m going to take mine -- I&#39;ve got a Bloomberg-y
question for you.
(Laughter.)
Mr. Spicer: I&#39;ve got a Sean-y answer for you.
(Laughter.)
The Press: The President in the Roosevelt Room
just said to us that, among other things, that
the tax plan is nearly finalized but it can&#39;t be
submitted until the healthcare plan
statutorily or otherwise is, so we&#39;re doing
the healthcare.
So what I wanted to clarify was, is the White
House doing a healthcare proposal, or was he
talking about Congress and not the White House?
Or is there a new plan?
Mr. Spicer: Well, obviously -- right.
So obviously there&#39;s two vehicles -- reconciliation
vehicles that -- FY17 -- I&#39;m going to give you a
Bloomberg-y answer.
(Laughter.)
The FY17 reconciliation, that
was never completed because the budget wasn&#39;t
finalized in the last Congress.
And then you&#39;ve got the 2018.
I think we want to make sure -- look at the
opportunities to work with Congress on Obamacare,
utilizing the 2017, and then you could utilize the
2018 reconciliation and budget process
to do tax reform.
That&#39;s not -- and again, that&#39;s not prescriptive.
I&#39;m not -- but as far as why the President is
saying it that way is because we&#39;ve got that
option available to us right now, and I think the
President is committed to making sure that the
promise that he made to the American people to
repeal and replace Obamacare continues to be
first and foremost, and then his tax plan.
But it&#39;s not a &quot;we can walk and chew gum&quot;
kind of thing.
We can actually work with Congress and the
leadership in both Houses.
The Press: President Obama used to say that.
Just to do the Bloomberg-y timeline, there&#39;s a few
things that are going to happen then.
There&#39;s going to be a budget plan that you guys
are going to present on March 13th-ish.
Mr. Spicer: Ish.
(Laughter.)
The Press: There&#39;s going to be a
healthcare -- this is where I got lost again --
something from him and something from them, and a
tax reform plan afterwards?
Is that the way it works?
Mr. Spicer: I don&#39;t want -- look, when we&#39;re ready
to announce stuff -- but I think again, I think
you&#39;ve got Obamacare, the budget, and tax reform.
It&#39;s going to be a very busy March and
April for us.
And we&#39;ve been continuing to work with Congress to
make sure that that&#39;s implemented.
Noah Bierman.
The Press: Does the President -- you were
talking about fulfilling his promises.
As you know, he promised during the campaign a
total and complete shutdown of Muslims
entering the country.
There were a lot of people in his party who thought
that was a very good proposal.
Can you explain his evolution in backing
down from that?
And can you also say whether he regrets using
that rhetoric, since it ended up hurting
the court case?
Mr. Spicer: Well, again, I&#39;d go back to the merits
of the case and the order that gives him the
authority to make that. U.S.
Code 1182 is very clear.
The President was very clear in his executive
order that these were countries that we didn&#39;t
have the proper vetting for when it came to
ensuring the safety of Americans.
That&#39;s what the executive order said.
The authority is very clear to have done it.
And I think that you&#39;re going to continue to see
the President take the steps necessary to
protect this country.
That&#39;s why he&#39;s talked about fighting this on
both fronts, making sure that we keep evolving
through the court system on the existing EO, and
then looking towards the next draft of the
executive order that will continue to achieve the
goal of protecting the American people.
So that&#39;s where we are.
That&#39;s what the order says.
And then so I think we continue to feel confident
that that&#39;s -- but it was crafted in a way that was
very clear about the countries, and was not
focused on anything else but the vetting
requirements that we have to make sure that we know
who&#39;s coming into this country and that they&#39;re
here not to do us any harm.
The Press: But when talking about fulfilling
his promises, can you explain why he decided to
back down from that one?
Because I know you differentiated this from
that promise.
Mr. Spicer: I think he&#39;s made it very clear, Noah,
from the beginning that this was a country-focused
issue, a safety-focused issue, and that&#39;s
why he issued it.
I don&#39;t see anything other than that with
reference to that.
Debra Saunders.
The Press: Hi.
The Oscars are Sunday night.
Will the President be watching?
If there&#39;s a Meryl Streep kind of moment, how do you
think he&#39;ll react?
And why -- if this has happened at other awards
ceremonies, why do you think this happens?
Mr. Spicer: Why do I think what happens?
(Laughter.)
The Press: Actresses and actors
like Meryl Streep.
Mr. Spicer: I have no idea.
It&#39;s a free country.
I think Hollywood is known for being rather far to
the left in its opinions.
And I&#39;ve got to be honest with you, I think the
President will be hosting
the Governors Ball that night.
Mrs. Trump looks forward to putting on a phenomenal
event, and the First Lady has put a lot of time into
this event that&#39;s going to occur in welcoming our
nation&#39;s governors to the Capitol.
And I have a feeling that that&#39;s where the President
and the First Lady are going to be focused on on
Sunday night, and so we&#39;ll go from there.
The Press: Sean, the President is going to have
a big audience next Tuesday in the joint
address to Congress.
Does he have a set of goals in mind
for the speech?
And do you think we&#39;re going to see some specific
policy rollouts as part of that speech?
Mr. Spicer: I think that the speech is going to
focus -- I mentioned this yesterday -- I think it&#39;s
going to talk -- remind the American people what
he&#39;s done already, and make sure that he explains
to them not just because of a sense of
accomplishment in moving this country forward, but
because I think it&#39;s important for the American
people to know that he was an agent of change, he
came here to get things done, and he didn&#39;t
waste any time.
He&#39;s committed to keeping his word.
And then I think he&#39;s going to lay out his
vision and talk about things like education and
healthcare and infrastructure, the
problems that we face as a country, the violence in
some of our inner cities, but also some of the
solutions that we can act on and some of the
partnerships that we can create.
It&#39;s obviously still a work in progress.
But I think it&#39;s going to look forward to where he
wants to take this country and talk about working
with Congress and other leaders throughout the
country to get things done.
But I think in the drafts that I&#39;ve seen so far, it
is going to be a very strong blueprint of where
he wants to take this country.
In the past, I think a lot of presidents -- or some
presidents, rather, have gotten into very
detailed specifics.
I think you&#39;re going to see him try to talk about
policies in a broad sense of where he wants to take
this country and what defining success is, what
that goal means.
But it&#39;s still a work in progress, and hopefully
towards the end of the week -- The Press: Is the
tone going to be optimistic, sunny?
Mr. Spicer: Yeah, I think this is an opportunity for
him to lay out a very positive vision for the
nation and to really let America know where we can
go and how we can get there, and the potential
that we have as a nation. Anita.
The Press: Just piggybacking on that, and
then I have another question.
Will he -- I know past presidents, including
President Obama, immediately hit the road
after -- I know this isn&#39;t a State of the Union, but
something like a State of the Union address
to sell policies.
And since you&#39;re saying it&#39;s more of a vision,
does he anticipate doing -- going out --
Mr. Spicer: Yeah, I think there will be some travel.
I don&#39;t want to -- that&#39;s evolving right now.
There&#39;s a lot of things
that we&#39;re trying to look at.
And I think as we look at the speech and some of the
objectives and goals and vision that he&#39;s sharing,
talk to him about potential places to go
to highlight that.
But I think you&#39;re going to see a fair amount of
visits in the next few weeks to highlight some of
the places that he wants to take them.
The Press: And then the other thing was, I&#39;ve seen
-- some members of Congress were
here last week.
There&#39;s the legislative meeting today.
It feels as if we haven&#39;t seen as many executive
actions -- or executive orders.
I know we have the one -- vetting one coming
out this week.
Are we in a different phase now that he&#39;s sort
of done the executive orders that he wants to do --
Mr. Spicer: No.
The Press: -- and we&#39;re going to legislation?
Mr. Spicer: We have several that are
in the pipeline.
And part of it is just -- these days are focused
with these meetings and getting things done and
trying to plan ahead.
And so as we see fit and as the implementation
process of a lot of these goes through the process,
we&#39;ll have future -- we&#39;ll have plenty more.
But -- The Press: It does seem that there&#39;s more
legislative emphasis right now.
Mr. Spicer: Well, it&#39;s both.
And I think part of this is as we work through
Congress, Anita, these are big things, right?
We&#39;re talking about fundamental tax reform --
something that hasn&#39;t happened in our
nation since 1986.
The repeal and replacement of Obamacare,
which was mammoth.
And I think part of this is that those
things take time.
He&#39;s got a joint address on Tuesday.
There&#39;s a lot of things that are happening, and
therefore we need to kind of make sure that we
appropriately use the schedule.
But I can assure you that if you&#39;ve missed executive
orders, you&#39;re going to see a bunch --
The Press: (Inaudible.)
Mr. Spicer: (Laughter.) I know.
I just want to make sure you know.
Jonathan Karl.
The Press: I want to ask you about the town halls,
and we&#39;re hearing about Obamacare.
The President referred to &quot;so-called angry crowds&quot;
at these town halls.
Is he suggesting this is manufactured anger, that
this is not real anger and real concern?
Mr. Spicer: Thanks.
I think there&#39;s a hybrid there.
I think some people are clearly upset.
But there is a bit of professional protestor,
manufactured base in there.
But obviously there are people that are upset.
But I also think that when you look at some of these
districts and some of these things, that it is
not a representation of a member&#39;s district or -- it
is a loud group, small group of people disrupting
something, in many cases, for media attention.
No offense.
It&#39;s just -- I think that necessarily -- just
because they&#39;re loud doesn&#39;t necessarily mean
that there are many.
And I think in a lot of cases that&#39;s
what you&#39;re seeing.
The Press: Does the President doubt that
there is real anger --
Mr. Spicer: No, I just said that.
The Press: -- and real concern out there beyond
just a few loud agitators, that there&#39;s real concern
that people may lose their healthcare?
Mr. Spicer: But see, I think that that&#39;s
a false narrative.
And I don&#39;t -- the President has
been very clear.
Look, you have to look at what our healthcare
system is right now.
In so many counties around our nation, we&#39;ve gone
down to one provider.
That&#39;s not choice.
That&#39;s not access.
And then they&#39;re going in a lot of cases and they&#39;re
saying, we&#39;re not taking Medicaid, we&#39;re not taking
TRICARE, we&#39;re not taking the insurance you used to
have; the doctor that you used to have isn&#39;t
participating anymore.
And, oh, by the way, states like Arizona,
you&#39;ve got over 100 percent increase in
premiums -- 112 [percent] I think was
the number there.
In many states, it&#39;s double, triple --
double-digit.
And I think that the idea that we have to remember
is that the American people got sold the
Affordable Care Act -- it&#39;s neither
affordable or accessible.
They&#39;re losing their coverage and premiums
are spiking.
And so if people are truly worried about losing their
coverage, they should be applauding the President&#39;s
action for wanting to make sure that we put a system
in place that does what they were supposed to have
been promised a while back.
And I think that&#39;s -- that&#39;s what I think is
missing from this dialogue.
I&#39;ve seen some folks that were protesting in some of
these things saying, I lost -- I&#39;m on Obamacare,
I&#39;m going to lose my thing.
And when they were asked how old they were, they
were, oh, I&#39;m 71, 72.
Well, they&#39;re not on Obamacare.
-- they&#39;re on Medicaid.
The Press: So you think you&#39;re making it up?
Mr. Spicer: No, not they&#39;re making it up.
But what I&#39;m getting at it is I think that there is a
lot of blurring of the facts.
And the reality is that some people
aren&#39;t on Obamacare.
They&#39;re on an employer-based system.
They&#39;re on Medicaid.
They&#39;re receiving their benefits through Medicare
because of their age.
And so they&#39;re in -- nothing.
They have no problems.
But I think in other cases, people are now
being told that the plan that they&#39;re on is
unsustainable; that these carriers throughout the
country -- I mean, you just look at them, over
and over again pulling out of the exchanges.
The reality is, is that they are losing their
healthcare, but they&#39;re losing it under Obamacare
because the exchanges are collapsing on themselves.
Carriers are pulling out.
Premiums are going up.
And access is going down.
So the President&#39;s plan is actually going to do
exactly what they were promised eight years ago
and didn&#39;t get.
So for those who are worried, the answer is:
Help is on the way.
The Press: But what is the plan?
We haven&#39;t seen what he&#39;s going to replace it with.
Mr. Spicer: First, as the President made clear,
we&#39;re going to have that out in the
next couple weeks.
He&#39;s working on it.
But the goal, Jonathan, is this got jammed through a
Democratic Congress, and then they told us you
could read it after we get it passed.
So taking our time, getting this right to
achieve the goals that we set forth is probably the
right thing to do, considering the experience
that we had the last time.
Hallie.
The Press: Sean, two questions for you.
The issue of transgender bathrooms wasn&#39;t one we
heard a lot about from the President
during the campaign.
He said at one point, Caitlyn Jenner could use
whichever bathroom she wanted to at Trump Tower.
So why is this now a priority for the
administration 40 days into office?
Mr. Spicer: It&#39;s not a priority.
I think there&#39;s a case -- The Press: But It&#39;s one
of the first things --
Mr. Spicer: But let me answer the question.
It&#39;s not a priority.
There is a case pending in the Supreme Court in which
we have to decide whether or not to continue to
issue guidance to the Court.
It&#39;s dictated by that.
The Obama administration had issued joint guidance
from the Department of Education and the
Department of Justice.
We now have to decide whether or not this
administration wants to continue that track that
they were on.
It&#39;s plain and simple.
If we don&#39;t -- but there are problems, both in the
legal and process way, in
which that guidance was issued.
And so it&#39;s incumbent upon us to actually follow the
law and to recognize that Title IX never
talked about this.
It was enacted in 1972.
There was no discussion of this back then.
And to assume certain elements of the law were
thought of back then with respect to this would be
completely preposterous.
The Press: And to be clear, Secretary DeVos is
onboard with this?
Mr. Spicer: Yes, 100 percent.
Thank you.
The Press: Sean, that was actually a clarification.
The second question is on Mexico.
The Secretary of State&#39;s trip that is tonight along
with Secretary Kelly, obviously there have been
tensions, right, between the Mexican President and
President Trump.
Is this a clean-up job for the Secretary of State?
Mr. Spicer: No.
I think that President Peña Nieto and President
Trump spoke -- again, the foreign ministers had
several contacts with our staff.
I would argue that we have a very healthy and robust
relationship with the Mexican government and
Mexican officials, and I think they would echo
that same sentiment.
President Peña Nieto has echoed that as well.
But I think the relationship with Mexico
is phenomenal right now, and I think there&#39;s an
unbelievable and robust dialogue between
our two nations.
Margaret, and then I&#39;ll get you.

The Press: Safe havens.
Mr. Spicer: Safe havens, thank you.

But I&#39;m not going to get ahead of the DOD on this.

The Press: Is there an NSC -- has the President

and Canada Council for

It occurred, what, six, seven days ago.
And so it&#39;s starting to work through the process

Zeke.
The Press: Thanks, Sean.
I have two questions for you.
One, earlier in your conversation with Jon,
does the White House not have confidence in its
Cabinet Secretaries if it&#39;s looking sort of over
their shoulders?
Does the White House not -- does the President not
trust his Cabinet Secretaries, appointees
and agency administrators to staff -- to find people
who agree with the President&#39;s agenda?
Mr. Spicer: No, not at all.
I think there&#39;s a big difference.
The President named these folks because they&#39;re
unbelievably qualified individuals.
Part of it, though, is that you&#39;re staffing major
departments and I think we&#39;ve got somewhere in the
area of 5,000 positions to fill.
And when you&#39;re filtering through a good number of
people, I don&#39;t even think the Secretaries, at some
degree, depending on the department, have a full
background on some of these individuals.
And so as they get pumped through the pipeline,
there are questions.
And, again, there are areas that are of key
priority to the President that he campaigned on.
And I think that when he wants to make sure that
certain of those individuals who are going
to be overseeing key priorities that he
promised the American people have somebody who
is not only qualified but agrees with and shares the
President&#39;s vision to fix whatever problem that was
or fulfill whatever vision that he articulated.
But I think that that -- I mean, it would almost be
malpractice not to do that.
To allow people to fill a job, a political appointee
job, who don&#39;t share the vision and agenda of the
President of the United States would almost be --
I mean, it would be silly on its face
to suggest this.
I don&#39;t think there&#39;s any administration in past
history that would literally, willingly, take
on somebody who was adamantly opposed or spoke
out specifically against what the President was
seeking to do, and then have them fulfill a job to
carry out that mission.
It just -- it doesn&#39;t seem
as though it makes any sense. Yes.
The Press: Second thing real quick.

What&#39;s the status of that review?

Mr. Spicer: Yes.

Mr. Spicer: I think General Dunford and

I know that the new National Security Advisor
is getting brought into that process and
continuing to do updates, so we&#39;ll have

But the team has been working on it since the
President issued the guidance. Yes.
The Press: As far as the second executive order is
concerned, what is the White House doing
differently in terms of consulting with various
departments to make certain that this second
executive order passes constitutional scrutiny?
Mr. Spicer: Well, I think we&#39;ve done a few things.
One is, I think we&#39;ve been very clear about
understanding what the court said in trying to
tailor that specifically while achieving the same
goals of keeping America safe and ensuring that
people don&#39;t come into this country that
seek to do us harm.
That&#39;s number one.
Number two is, we continue -- and that order is
basically completed.
I think what we&#39;re now doing is working with the
various agencies and departments to make sure
that the implementation of that is done in an
extremely smooth way.
So we have looked at it from both a process
standpoint, as well as a legal standpoint.
And I think it&#39;s achieving the goals.
But again, I would also mention that, on the
merits, I believe that the first order did just that.
It was written in a way -- and I think ultimately we
will continue to prevail on that -- because it is
written in a way that is
clear and consistent with U.S.
code and the authority that the President has to
protect the nation. Katie.
The Press: Sean --
The Press: No matter what
happens, as it relates to the second executive
order, it&#39;s almost likely to face a legal challenge.
Mr. Spicer: Sure.
The Press: Are you concerned that the
President&#39;s prior remarks as it relates to the
judiciary is going to allow him to get a fair
hearing by the judicial branch as it relates to
the second executive order?
Mr. Spicer: Yeah, absolutely.
I think that --
The Press: Why do you say that?
Mr. Spicer: Because I think that you&#39;ve seen it
happen in the Massachusetts case.
I mean, at the end of the day, you look at the law
and what the order does.
And I think, again, you may have -- in the case of
the 9th Circuit, we
continue to disagree with that.
I think the President has pointed out you don&#39;t have
to be that high up in grade school to recognize
what the code says, what the authority that is
granted to him, and then what the order does.
I think the things that they brought out in that
order -- in one of the cases, they suggested
there have been no people that have entered within
the seven countries.
And a quick cursory look found upwards of close to
20 people that had come in.
So some of the basis for which they decided the
case on doesn&#39;t actually pass muster.
And I think any other judge or judges that look
at that order or the one that will be put forward
will come to the same conclusion. Katie.
